properties.description: A fire engine en route to a fire got stuck behind a stationary Recology garbage truck. A Cruise driverless car going in the opposite direction stopped right next to the garbage truck, making it impossible to drive around. The fire engine was "dead in the water" until Recology workers moved their truck.
Firefighters were battling a fire when a driverless car going west drove over their fire hoses at 10 to 15 miles per hour. The reporting firefighter called its driving "hazardous."

At an active fire, a driverless car moved toward the scene and "was going to run over our hoses," wrote the reporting firefighter. He yelled at the car to stop, banged his fist on the hood and, when the car kept coming, he smashed its window.

A crew was fighting a fire on the sidewalk. A Cruise car drove between the firefighters and their engine, and "stopped on top of our hoseline." A firefighter spoke to a Cruise operator through the car intercom and, after five minutes, the car moved away.
A fire truck returning from a call was blocked by "two autonomous Cruise vehicles blocking the road." The reporting firefighter said that the cars did not respond to the fire engine's truck or horn.

A firefighting crew was responding to a tree that had fallen on a vehicle. Two Waymo driverless cars came toward the firefighters at pace and "slowed down last minute." The reporting firefighter said the cars put his crew at risk.

While clearing up downed trees, two Cruise driverless cars drove through the firefighters' caution tape. They plowed into fallen Muni electrical wires, which got tangled in their roof cameras. Firefighters "took manual control of the vehicles."
Firefighters were conducting a "hose line drill" outside the fire station. A driverless car drove past safety cones and right into the hose's stream, then pulled over and activated its hazard lights.
A fire engine was blocked from getting close to a reported fire by a Cruise driverless car. The car "created an obstacle for water supply." The fire was ultimately a false alarm.
A Waymo driverless car blocked a fire truck en route to an incident. The firefighters spoke to a remote operator via the car's intercom. The operator agreed to move but the car remained stationary.

While firefighters were battling a fire, a Cruise driverless car slowly moved toward one of their fire engines. A firefighter placed "chalk blocks" in front of the car to stop it jeopardizing their water supply. After 10 minutes on the phone to a Cruise representative, the car backed away.
En route to a building alarm, a Cruise car was blocking traffic and "lurching forward in uneven movements." The reporting firefighter said that the car "came too close" to their fire engine.

Firefighters were battling a fire when a Cruise car drove up to the scene, "approximately ten feet" from their fire engine. The firefighters "attempted to disable the vehicle" and it drove away ten minutes later "of its own accord."

A Cruise driverless car stopped "approximately 6 feet" from a fire engine responding to an incident. The car came "close to compromising a hose lead." Firefighters began "poking and prodding the vehicle, and pounding on the windows." A remote operator ultimately drove the car away.

When firefighters responded to a building alarm, a Cruise driverless car "attempted to squeeze past" two fire engines. "As these autonomous vehicles are learning traffic patterns they have become more aggressive with first responder units and their attempts to navigate around them," wrote the reporting firefighter.
